data.title: Suggestion: non-blocking breakpoints
data.body:
I realize very few people know this exists, but it's very useful in realtime and GUI development.

**Situation:**
Breakpoints are useful, but because they suspend the game, you can only stare at a fixed point in time while leaving your game unresponsive.
If you want to see how frequently some code is called, in what order, or how a value changes over time, you have to modify your code and print stuff. The problem with that solution is that you loose a lot of time doing it if your game runs on a device, or if you have to run a long series of actions in the game before reaching the point where the bug is (not to mention asynchronous or time-dependent tasks where breaking would prevent an action from being repro-ed correctly). Also, script hot-reloading is not always an option because it could be risky, and it doesn't even works well on my own game.

**The idea**
The idea is that a breakpoint could also, instead of breaking, print a message, retrieve the stack, or display the value of available variables. Or eventually break if a condition is fullfilled. This alternative doesn't requires code modifications and would be very fast to setup.

Now I don't necessarily need it currently, but maybe others could be interested by the idea. I use a similar feature in Visual Studio on a daily basis due to the complexity of the project, and it saves a significant amount of time.

data.title: More custom theme support for editor
data.body: Now ProjectManger and EditorLog can show with custom themes.

data.title: Fix manifest generation bug in Android export
data.body:
Related if not a total fix for #4777.

This was a memory bug. After resizing a vector and potentially resizing it again with `push_back`, pointers held to data become invalid. So depending on the circumstances (release vs. debug, allocation chunk size, current size of allocated block, etc.) `chars` may be pointing to old memory and writes through it don't end up where they should and, moreover, they could be smashing other data or cause SEGFAULTS.

(I'm detailing the bug report with a general explanation because this may serve for future reference for someone.)

data.title: removed redundant assign operation in mesh_add_surface
data.body:
'elem_count' was assigned twice.

cppcheck messages:

[rasterizer_gles2.cpp:2001] -> [rasterizer_gles2.cpp:2006]: (performance) Variable 'elem_count' is reassigned a value before the old one has been used.
[rasterizer_gles2.cpp:2010] -> [rasterizer_gles2.cpp:2014]: (performance) Variable 'elem_count' is reassigned a value before the old one has been used.
[rasterizer_gles2.cpp:2022] -> [rasterizer_gles2.cpp:2026]: (performance) Variable 'elem_count' is reassigned a value before the old one has been used.
[rasterizer_gles2.cpp:2030] -> [rasterizer_gles2.cpp:2034]: (performance) Variable 'elem_count' is reassigned a value before the old one has been used.

data.title: Feature: Promotable Properties
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Any platform, Godot 2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

I may be approaching my node hierarchy design incorrectly in which case feedback is welcome, but I think there may be an interesting feature possibility based on the little bit of experience that I have.

I think it would be interesting if there was a way for a parent node to promote specific properties of its children, so that when the parent is instanced into a scene that those child properties could be set directly for that instance, rather than replicated from parent to children by script. 

An example...

I've created a Player scene hierarchy that I instantiate into my scene for each game player. Right now my player scene looks like

```
 player (RigidBody2D)
  - Sprite
  - CollisionPolygon2D
  - control_move(Node)
```

`control_move` is just a node with a script attached that implements simple controls, it exposes a variable `player_speed`,`player_number`. Its `player_number` is used to build an Input name unique to that player's controls. I may move this in to a plugin later.

Right now my player parent node _also_ has to expose `player_number`, and it has to pass this along at initialization to its child. Player parent also exposes an `extern (Texture) texture` which it passes along to the Sprite child:

``` godot
func _ready():
    get_node("Sprite").set_texture(texture)
    control.player_number = player_number
```

In a perfect world, `player` could simply promote the texture of `Sprite` and `player_number` from those child nodes, so that when instanced I could set those properties on player and then I wouldn't need any script at all in player - the engine would transparently reference the actual property for me. 

As for implementation - well that I am not qualified to say but perhaps a dynamic script object would have to be created for the parent class, and any user defined script would have to subclass that. Probably not nearly as simple as the idea is - but any alternative ideas are welcome.

Now it does not try to build if the solution is not found. This way it's
possible to provide a minimal package with includes and libs and make it

Also remove messages from detect.py since it is ran for every platform

data.title: Main Screen plugin crashes editor if its screen is shown when plugin is deactivated
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot v2.2a x11

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I had my plugin's editor screen open when disabling it (enable/disable cycle occurs rather often whilst testing a plugin).  It blanked the view but then the editor crashed when I tried to navigate to a different view (2D/3D/Script or AssetLib).

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create plugin that installs a main screen scene (see attached addon sample)
Activate the plugin in project settings.
(plugin now in view list)
Navigate view to plugin's screen.
Deactivate the plugin in project settings.
(view is now blank, plugin gone from view list)
Attempt to change to a different view, say Script (it could be any).

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[test_addon.tar.gz](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/483195/test_addon.tar.gz)

data.title: exported vars can be exported several times
Tween not setting global_pos properly
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1 Stable, Ubuntu 16.04 and Android 6

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I'm using Tween to move a Sprite to a new global position (37, 545), but at the end of the transition, it's being placed at (36.999989, 545) and sometimes at (36, 545). 

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a Sprite with a Tween node child and try this code:

```
extends Sprite

onready var tween = get_node("Tween")

func _ready():
    var new_pos = Vector2(37, 545)
    tween.interpolate_method(self , "set_global_pos", get_global_pos(), new_pos, 0.3, Tween.TRANS_SINE , Tween.EASE_IN)
    tween.start()
    yield(tween, "tween_complete")
    print(get_global_pos())
```

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: fixes #6487, GDscript compiler ignores OPCODE_LINE and OPCODE_BREAKPOINT in Release mode
data.body:
When godot is in release mode, GDscript compiler does not generate
bytecodes for OPCODE_LINE and OPCODE_BREAKPOINT anymore.

This optimizes GDscript execution speed when the script contains a lot
of comments in blocs executed in loops.

Fixes #6487

data.title: fixes #6487, GDscript compiler ignores OPCODE_LINE and OPCODE_BREAKPOINT in Release mode
data.body:
When godot is in release mode, GDscript compiler does not generate bytecodes for OPCODE_LINE and OPCODE_BREAKPOINT anymore.

This optimizes GDscript execution speed when the script contains a lot of comments in blocs executed in loops.

Fixes #6487

data.title: Frame property of Sprite node still indicates 0 in the Inspector panel after changing it
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 16.04 - v2.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
After changing the `Frame` property of the `Sprite` node, the number is still 0 in the `Inspector` panel. The texture itself updates, but the `Inspector` `Frame` property still indicates 0. And when using the up/down arrows for this property the frame jumps at 0.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Make a new scene, add a sprite node to it, load a texture, set `Vframes`, `Hframes` and try modifying the `Frame` property.

When using `scons platform=windows CXX=<custom-compiler>` and MinGW is autodetected the compilation still starts using gcc and not the custom compiler provided. I expected to invoke the build using the custom compiler provided. When using the Visual Studio Command Prompt it is running fine.

I am trying with clang as CXX but I am not sure if this is a problem with scons itself.

**Steps to reproduce:**
See above

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
N/A

data.title: Clang on Windows using clang-cl
data.body:
Hello, today I have tried some configurations on building Godot using LLVM on Windows.
The easiest way to do this seem to be by using the clang-cl wrapper as a compiler using the following command line from the VS2015 command prompt:

```
scons platform=windows CXX=clang-cl CCFLAGS=/EHsc
```

The compilation is running fine until linking where I get a missing symbol `InterlockedCompareExchange64` in `baked_light_baker_cmpxchg.cpp` which seems that can be fixed by adding an `#include <intrin.h>` under `#include "windows.h"`. 

Once I did this I was able to compile godot without problems: ~~[test build](https://1drv.ms/u/s!AtCKgU6ij1Tyi_AGvzJlecrHmaoaQg)~~ (this is unfortunately only compiled half with clang as it has only the C++ files compiled and not the C ones). [dependency graph](http://screencast.com/t/l3rIyXkt9gN9)

I am also currently testing with normal clang without the wrapper. I'll edit this as soon as I have some results (seems that CXX variabile is not taken in count when using mingw).

EDIT: seems that clang on Windows (LLVM official) is more tied to Visual Studio than MinGW. I am going to change my plans accordingly

I am open to discussion on this as at the moment it is just a Proof of Concept.

data.title: Clang on Windows Compilation via clang-cl
data.body:
Hello, I am not sure on how to work with this as what I have here is a merely Proof of Concept.

After fiddling a bit with LLVM and the `clang-cl` wrapper I managed to provide a compilation of Godot (master) using LLVM on Windows.

I am open to discussion on how to implement this if there is interest. Meanwhile I can provide a build for testing (64bit only) [here](https://1drv.ms/u/s!AtCKgU6ij1Tyi_AGvzJlecrHmaoaQg)

data.title: A bucket of issues with OptionButton (Dropdown)
data.body:
(Godot build from 20.09.16)
# Deleting Items

If you select an item and delete the same item, OptionButton does not change the selected text visible.
If you use the clear() function, selected id turns to -1 and there won't be any text visible; however, if you delete the last item without using clear(), selected item is still 0.

A possible solution, If you are deleting last item is to set selected id to -1

Another possibility would be to add an extra optional bool in remove_item() where false would be to return to the first item (if any) or -1 if it was the last item. True could be to move to the next item in selection (i.e. you delete ID 3, you select the new ID at 3).

Currently, when there are more items; simply deleting selected item will just 

---
# Selecting previously deleted ID

Currently when you try to select another item which have the same ID like the deleted item, it wont allow you to select it. 
1. Delete item#1 with ID 3
2. Item#2 takes the place if ID3 after item#1 is gone
3. Attempting to select item#2 does not work.

---
# Adding an Item

After deleting the last item (having selected id at 0, problem with deletion), adding a new item does not automatically select the first item.

If you fix the problem with deletion, the selected_id should by default be -1 (when there are no previous item added) - which should automatically set selected to 0 when the first item is added.
(Of course you should not automatically select the LAST item if there are previous items available)

---
# Cannot set selected to none

You are unable to set selected to -1 (none). You can use .select(id) to choose any existing ID, but we should definitely implement the option to set to -1 (none), which also is the same selected id you get when you use .clear().

---
# OptionButton is a misleading name

Godot would benefit from renaming OptionButton to DropdownButton or something similar that gives you the perfect description of what it is. :)

data.title: Crash when opening invalid XML scene
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 . Godot Version 2.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I was trying to open a .tscn file. By mistake, I hit an XML file. Godot crashes. 

This looks silly, but somebody could lost unsaved work if it happens.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open a project which has XML file. Go to Open Scene, and select that wrong XML File.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

Open godot demos. Open 3d In 2D example. Click on Scene -> Open Scene. Select player.xml.
Godot crashes.

data.title: Show True/False tooltip in property editor for bool values
data.body: Showing **On** text in tooltip when checkbox is unchecked may be misleading. Probably it's better to show **True/False**.

data.title: Use full width of TreeItem::Cell to change value in CELL_MODE_CHECK
data.body:
I think TreeItem::Cell in CELL_MODE_CHECK should use all its width to set/unset it's value.
It's user friendly and it is consistent with CheckBox control (which uses it's label for changing value) or cell in CELL_MODE_STRING which uses all it's width to gather clicks to start editing (user does not need to hit entered text, which would be even impossible when text is empty).
Maybe there was purpose to narrow clicks to cell texture before, but I see no reason to force user to aim this small rectangle.

data.title: Expose Vector2::clamped() to scripts
data.body:
Needed this and wondered that there's no built-in function for it.
So I wanted to implement it and saw that it's actually already there, just wasn't bound ^^

data.title: Add docs for XMLparser, VideoPlayer and most of Tree
Apk not designed for tablets - possible "Support Large" and "Support Xlarge" export option problem.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux Xubuntu 14.04 64-bit, Godot 2.1-alpha and Godot 1.1 - both custom compile.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
After properly uploading apk to Google Play Developer Console, Google gives me following notification
![Message from Google Play](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11817561/18644993/bdd4cc34-7eab-11e6-82b8-4e3f6f492050.png)

My export settings about screen sizes look like this
![Godot Export Options](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11817561/18645027/e2ce0d2a-7eab-11e6-929e-bab43f41c1f8.png)

**Steps to reproduce:**
To see the notification in Google Plays Development Console you need to choose one of your apps from your app's list and go to Statistics. 
![Google Play Statistics](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11817561/18645485/a60bbbe2-7ead-11e6-9758-6b3a13cdec13.png)
Then in the middle of stats page, which shows "Android Version" stats by default, ![Android Version](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11817561/18645531/d8b6f32c-7ead-11e6-84fe-d1126eafa27f.png)
you need to change it to "Tablets", and in the lover part of the page you should be able to  see something like this

![Stats with the Tablet notofication](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11817561/18645564/f97d54e8-7ead-11e6-9860-a0a5119db631.png)

data.title: Make Variant REAL name double if REAL_T_IS_DOUBLE is defined
data.body: @reduz IINW, you plan to use `double` instead of `float` in 3.0. I guess you will use `real_t` and the `REAL_T_IS_DOUBLE` macro for this. If that's the case, this change would help me when generating the C# bindings.

data.title: Canvas item shader SRC_VERTEX wrong in TileMap
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10x x64, (almost) latest master

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
`SRC_VERTEX` for `CanvasItemShader`s is expected to be relative to it's local space, ~~but when texture region is in effect, it's offset by the position of the sub-rect in the full texture.
Is this intended behavior? Won't this also change shader output when the game is packaged with atlasing?~~, but when used for tiles in a `TileMap` it's relative to the current quadrant instead of the current individual cell.
Is this intended behavior?

I see that `TileMap` builds a `CanvasItem` for every quadrant so what the docs say about `SRC_VERTEX` is still true and probably this behavior is expected, but then what would be a workaround to get the cell-local vertex in the shader code?

**Steps to reproduce:**
N/A

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
Probably if I can devote some more time.
